content: The Act is titled the "Surface Transportation Security Improvement Act of 2018" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Surface Transportation Security Improvement Act of 2018" defines terms such as "appropriate congressional committees," "public and private sector stakeholders," and "surface transportation asset." The "Surface Transportation Security Improvement Act of 2018" includes definitions for various transportation entities, such as railroad carriers, over-the-road bus services, bus terminals, and other transportation facilities as determined by the Secretary. The "Surface Transportation Security Improvement Act of 2018" includes definitions for various transportation entities, such as railroad carriers, over-the-road bus services, bus terminals, and other transportation facilities as determined by the Secretary. Additionally, the act includes a provision for a national strategy for transportation security review. The Comptroller General of the United States will evaluate the 2016 Biennial National Strategy for Transportation Security within one year of the Act's enactment. The evaluation will assess the strategy's impact on Federal transportation security programs, budgets, research, and staffing levels. Key considerations include the strategy's forward-looking nature, its influence on future Federal efforts, and alignment with annual progress reports submitted to Congress. The annual progress reports submitted to Congress after the issuance of the 2016 Biennial National Strategy for Transportation Security evaluate how well the strategy guides Federal efforts in transportation security. SEC. 4. RISK SCENARIOS. The Secretary of Homeland Security annually develops risk-based priorities for transportation modes based on assessments of threats, vulnerabilities, and consequences. These priorities are informed by terrorist attack scenarios, including cyber attacks, and intelligence on evolving threats. A report must be provided to congressional committees within 120 days of each priority development. The Secretary of Homeland Security annually develops risk-based priorities for transportation modes based on assessments of threats, vulnerabilities, and consequences. A report is required to include copies of risk assessments, a summary ranking risks, and descriptions of risk-based priorities for securing the transportation sector. Information on methodologies used to assess risks and the basis for assumptions may be classified or unclassified. SEC. 5. ASSESSMENTS AND SECURITY PLANS; FRONTLINE EMPLOYEE SECURITY TRAINING. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report to Congress and the Inspector General on the status of regulations for security assessments, plans, and training programs for transportation employees to address potential security threats. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report to Congress and the Inspector General on security regulations for transportation employees to address security threats. The Inspector General will review the report and provide recommendations for finalizing rulemaking and ensuring regulation implementation. SEC. 6. RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT. The Secretary of Homeland Security will assess the feasibility of enhancing surface transportation security by integrating next-generation technologies for detecting explosives and providing operators access to the Transportation Security Administration's Secure. The Secretary of Homeland Security will assess enhancing surface transportation security by integrating next-generation technologies for detecting explosives, providing operators access to the Secure Flight Program, deploying credential authentication technology for passenger vetting, and implementing scalable technology solutions for threat detection within high-risk transportation assets. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in coordination with the Transportation Security Administration, will address technological, privacy, operational, passenger facilitation, and public acceptance considerations for security measures in surface transportation. The Secretary of Homeland Security will disseminate best practices for enhancing transportation security against vehicle-based terrorist attacks within 180 days. Additionally, a stakeholder survey on surface transportation will be conducted. SEC. 8. The Secretary of Homeland Security will conduct a survey of public and private stakeholders on resource challenges in securing surface transportation assets. A report on the survey results and efforts to address security vulnerabilities will be submitted to congressional committees. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration may establish a task force to collaborate with stakeholders to develop innovative technology for transportation security, including field demonstrations, data gathering, and funding support for small businesses. The task force authorized by the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration will be chaired by their designee and include representatives appointed in consultation with the Chairperson of the Aviation Security Advisory Committee. The task force will evaluate technologies for surface transportation security, coordinate with the Department of Homeland Security's Science and Technology Directorate, and submit an annual report to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The task force, chaired by the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration, evaluates technologies for surface transportation security and submits an annual report to the Secretary of Homeland Security. The report identifies transportation modes that could benefit from technology integration and includes deployment plans. The Administrator is not required to acquire innovative technology, and the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the task force. SEC. 10. Security technologies tied to foreign threat countries require an assessment of threats posed by technologies from countries with cyber or homeland security risks. SEC. 11. Surface transportation security inspectors are addressed. SEC. 11. Surface transportation security inspectors must submit a strategy within 180 days to address data system limitations, align operations with risk assessments, and establish measurable objectives for the program. The Comptroller General will review the strategy within the same timeframe. The United States will review the strategy and issue recommendations. Passed by the House of Representatives on March 22, 2018. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
